Award.AwardTitle: Building an EPSCoR Community for Science and Technology Innovation
Award.AbstractNarration: This grant will facilitate participation by Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) jurisdictions in a conference focused on expanding the capacity to impact economic development. The Arkansas Economic Development Commission (AEDC) will use the funds to provide stipends to EPSCoR program staff and their colleagues from jurisdictional economic development and policy offices to attend the State Science and Technology Institute’s (SSTI) annual meeting. Further, AEDC and SSTI will work with an advisory committee of EPSCoR jurisdictions to produce a pre-conference roundtable and a track of sessions within the full conference agenda. This structure will provide opportunities to improve EPSCoR jurisdictions’ impacts by expanding knowledge of others’ activities and building denser professional networks within and across jurisdictions.<br/><br/>As a means of strengthening the economic development and research capacity potential of EPSCoR jurisdictions, AEDC will convene EPSCoR stakeholders—including jurisdictional office staff, commercialization and economic development professionals, and policymakers—for the SSTI annual meeting in Little Rock, Arkansas. During the three-day event focused on strengthening innovation economies, AEDC and SSTI will convene multiple sessions of interest to EPSCoR stakeholders, including a track of sessions specifically related to universities’ roles in economic development, and will hold a roundtable specifically for attendees from EPSCoR jurisdictions to discuss how they can more effectively leverage university R&D to generate greater investment in research capacity and economic development outcomes. The conference therefore provides an opportunity to bring together the EPSCoR and economic development practitioner communities to strengthen connections and expand the opportunities for peer learning and discussion, which should translate to improved economic development impacts in EPSCoR jurisdictions. The grant will enable AEDC to create a scholarship program for EPSCoR stakeholders to attend the conference, with scholarship awardees then providing detailed feedback on how the information and connections available at the event may inform future policies or activities in their jurisdiction.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this workshop was to bring together stakeholders in the research and innovation sector ? including state NSF EPSCoR staff, commercialization professionals, and state policymakers ? to share and learn best practices, discuss resources and Federal initiatives, and foster collaborative relationships among peers in EPSCoR jurisdictions. The workshop award primarily provided travel support for people from EPSCoR jurisdictions to attend the National State Science & Technology Institute (SSTI) annual conference in May 2022. The workshop and conference were originally scheduled for October of 2020 but were delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

The conference was held May 2-4, 2022 in Little Rock, Arkansas. More details about the event can be found on the conference website: https://2022.ssticonference.org/  

SSTI?s 2022 Annual Conference had a total of 276 registered attendees. Of this total, 139 people representing 17 of the EPSCoR jurisdictions attended (75 of these lived in the host state of Arkansas, leaving 64 from the other 16 represented jurisdictions). 35 attendees from EPSCoR jurisdictions received support to attend the conference through the EPS-WO award. The EPSCoR jurisdictions represented at the conference were: Alaska; Alabama; Arkansas; Delaware; Iowa; Kansas; Kentucky; Louisiana; Maine; Mississippi; Nebraska; New Mexico; Oklahoma; South Carolina; South Dakota; Vermont; and West Virginia.

In recognition of the concentration of NSF?s support through this award and the large concentration of attendees from EPSCoR jurisdictions, SSTI?s 2022 Annual Conference included an 'EPSCoR track' of sessions intended to support the needs and interests of these attendees. These sessions included: EPSCoR-focused roundtable discussion on jurisdictional research competitiveness & innovation (invitation only workshop for EPSCoR scholarship recipients); Extending R&D assets to find 1+1=3; Strengthening support among natural allies: EPSCoR and economic development orgs; Setting a vision: Higher education?s new roles in growing economic prosperity; and Federal resources to build research and innovation capacity.

Attendees from EPSCoR jurisdictions discussed barriers and successes in increasing research competitiveness, commercialization of EPSCoR research, and relationships with innovation and entrepreneurial support organizations, and economic development organizations. Participants said they appreciated the ?stimulating, thought provoking, honest and valuable? discussions and found them impactful and relevant.

Other conference sessions focused on different elements of technology-based economic development, from an innovation agenda and governors? campaigns to better metrics for TBED initiatives, to capital access programs and supporting diverse entrepreneurs, and more. One key element of all SSTI conferences are the opportunities that are designed to encourage networking among all the participants, to make greater connections and learn about new programs and problem solving happening in other regions around the country. 

The conference had several sessions related to tech transfer and commercialization. One session focused on legal structures of venture development organizations. A panel discussion was held featuring several Arkansas researchers who became entrepreneurs and brought research to the market. Another session focused explicitly on supporting Black, Latino, and female innovators, another on econometric models to assess tech-based economic development initiatives.

A significant impact of this workshop was bringing together attendees, many of whom had not traveled since before the pandemic, to discuss the innovation economy. The conference took place during the same week that NSF announced the Regional Innovation Engines program, and having a program officer in attendance (Daniel Goetzel) provided a great resource to the other attendees. This workshop award can be largely credited with the submission of at least one Type-1 innovation engines proposal- many of the collaborators in the Type-1 proposal submitted by the Arkansas Center for Health Improvement met at the SSTI conference and had initial discussions that resulted in the submission. It is likely also true for other proposals, especially to the Engines program. The development of that proposal alone brought together a wide array of researchers, medical professionals, financial institutions, community advocates, and entrepreneurial support staff from across Arkansas, Louisiana, and Mississippi. The proposal is currently under review, but the consortium behind it is actively working to leverage additional support and strategically plan innovation activities in the region and make a significant impact in the Mississippi River Delta region and beyond.

Plenary sessions included a presentation from SSTI President Dan Berglund who discussed the record levels of federal and state funding available for strategic investment in the tech-based economy, and keynote speaker Carter Malloy, founder and CEO of AcreTrader. AcreTrader addresses the high cost of entry and the burden of farm management that keeps farmland inaccessible to the average investor. At the same time, it provides an opportunity to provide farmers with innovative routes to capital for expansion. 

Overall the workshop and conference served to unite stakeholders at a unique time, leading to the formation of countless new relationships that will hopefully result in quantifiable impact to the country?s science and technology innovation landscape.
